Chapter 12, Part 4: The Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa
Good sons!
The TathÄgata also has words that accord with his own intentions.
The Buddha-nature of the TathÄgata is of two kinds:
One is existent, and the other is nonexistent.

The existent refers to the thirty-two marks, eighty minor marks, ten powers, four fearlessnesses, three foundations of mindfulness, great compassion, the immeasurable samÄdhis such as the Å›Å«raá¹ƒgama, the immeasurable samÄdhis such as the vajra, the immeasurable samÄdhis such as skillful means, and the immeasurable samÄdhis such as the five seals of wisdom. This is called the existent.

The nonexistent refers to the TathÄgata, past wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate karmic causes, effects, and retributions, afflictions, the five aggregates, and the twelve links of dependent arising. This is called the nonexistent.
Good sons!
There is existence and nonexistence, wholesome and unwholesome, contaminated and uncontaminated, worldly and non-worldly,
The world, the holy and the non-holy, the conditioned and the unconditioned, the real and the unreal, the tranquil and the non-tranquil,
the contentious and the non-contentious, the realm and the non-realm, the afflictions and the non-afflictions,
the grasping and the non-grasping, the prediction and the non-prediction, existence and non-existence,
the three times and the non-three times, the timely and the untimely, the permanent and the impermanent, the self and the non-self,
happiness and non-happiness, purity and impurity, form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, and the non-form,
feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, the internal sense bases and the non-internal sense bases, the external sense bases and the non-external sense bases,
the twelve links of dependent arising and the non-twelve links of dependent arising - this is called the existence and non-existence of the TathÄgata's Buddha-nature.
Up to the existence and non-existence of the Buddha-nature of the icchantika are also like this.
Good son!
Although I say that all sentient beings have Buddha-nature, sentient beings do not understand the Buddha's words that accord with their own intentions.
Good son!
Such words, even a bodhisattva in the final stage cannot understand, let alone the two vehicles and other bodhisattvas.
Good man!
Once, I was on Vulture Peak, discussing conventional truth with Maitreya Bodhisattva.
ÅšÄriputra and the other five hundred voice-hearers did not understand this matter at all, let alone the ultimate truth beyond the world.
Good man!ğŸ”½Some say that the Buddha-nature exists in icchantikas but not in those with wholesome roots.
Some say that the Buddha-nature exists in those with wholesome roots but not in icchantikas.
Some say that the Buddha-nature exists in both kinds of people.
Some say that the Buddha-nature does not exist in either kind of person.
Good man!
If my disciples understand the meaning of these four statements, they should not argue that icchantikas definitely have the Buddha-nature or definitely do not have the Buddha-nature.
If it is said that all sentient beings have the Buddha-nature, this is called the TathÄgata's speech in accordance with his own intention.
How can sentient beings understand the TathÄgata's words in this way?
Good man!
In the Ganges River there are seven kinds of beings:

1) Those who always sink, 2) Those who temporarily emerge but sink again, 3) Those who emerge and then stay, 4) Those who emerge and look around in all directions, 5) Those who look around and then move, 6) Those who move and then stay again, 7) Those who move both in the water and on land.
Those who always sink refer to large fish that experience great evil karma, their bodies heavy and in deep water, and thus they always sink.

Those who temporarily emerge but sink again refer to large fish that, due to experiencing evil karma, have heavy bodies and are in shallow water, temporarily seeing light, and because of the light they emerge, but because they are heavy they sink again.
Those who emerge and then stay refer to fish such as the tilapia, whose bodies are in shallow water and enjoy seeing light, so they emerge and then stay.
Those who look around in all directions refer to fish such as the carp, who look around in all directions in search of food, and thus they look around in all directions.
Observing and then acting refers to a fish that sees something from afar that it thinks is edible, and quickly swims towards it, thus observing and then acting.
Acting and then stopping means that after the fish has approached and obtained something edible, it then stops, thus acting and then stopping.
Moving both in water and on land refers to a turtle.
Good man!
This river of the subtle and wonderful great parinirvÄá¹‡a also has seven kinds of beings, from the first who are always submerged to the seventh who may enter or exit.

As for those who are submerged, there are people who hear this MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, that the TathÄgata abides permanently, without change, with permanence, bliss, self, and purity, and will never finally enter nirvÄá¹‡a;

that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature, that icchantikas who slander the vaipulya sÅ«tras, commit the five heinous crimes, and violate the four grave prohibitions will definitely attain the path to bodhi;
SrotÄpannas, saká¹›dÄgÄmins, anÄgÄmins, arhats, and pratyekabuddhas will definitely attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Having heard these words, they give rise to faithless thoughts. Having given rise to these thoughts, they say:
This Nirvana Sutra is a book of non-Buddhists, not a Buddhist sutra.

At that time, these people are far from good friends and do not hear the true Dharma. Although they may sometimes hear it, they cannot contemplate it. Although they may contemplate it, they do not contemplate goodness. Because they do not contemplate goodness, they abide in evil dharmas.
Abiding in evil dharmas means there are six kinds:
First, evil; second, no goodness; third, defiled dharmas; fourth, increasing existence; fifth, vexation and heat; sixth, receiving evil fruits.
This is called sinking.
Why is it called sinking?
Because there is no wholesome mind, because one always engages in evil, and because one does not cultivate antidotes, this is called sinking.

As for what is called evil, it is because sages rebuke it, because it causes fear in the mind, because good people stay far away from it, and because it does not benefit sentient beings. This is called evil.

As for what is called lacking wholesomeness, it is because it can give rise to immeasurable evil karmic retributions, because it is always entangled by ignorance, because it delights in being an equal companion with evil people, because there are no skillful means for cultivating goodness, and because the mind is inverted and always mistaken. This is called lacking wholesomeness.

As for what is called defiling the Dharma, it is because it always defiles body, speech, and mind, because it defiles pure sentient beings, because it increases unwholesome karma, and because it stays far away from wholesome dharmas. This is called defiling the Dharma.

As for what is called increasing existence, the dharmas practiced by the above three types of people can increase hell, animal realms, and hungry ghosts, and they are unable to cultivate the Dharma of liberation. The actions of body, speech, and mind do not detest existence. This is called increasing existence.

As for the word heat, this person fully engages in the above four things, which can cause both body and mind to be troubled and hot, far removed from tranquility, and is therefore called heat. Because one receives the retribution of hell, it is called heat. Because it burns all sentient beings, it is called heat. Because it burns all wholesome dharmas, it is called heat.
Good son!
Faith and coolness are not possessed by this person, and therefore it is called heat.
As for receiving evil fruits, this person fully engages in the above five things and, upon death, falls into hell, hungry ghosts, or the animal realm.
Good son!

There are three evil things that are also called evil fruits: first, the evil of afflictions, second, the evil of karma, and third, the evil of retribution. These are called receiving evil fruits and retributions.
Good son!

This person, endowed with the above six things, can sever wholesome roots, commit the five heinous crimes, violate the four grave prohibitions, slander the Three Jewels, use the Sangha's possessions, and do various kinds of improper things. For these causes and conditions, they will sink and drown in AvÄ«ci Hell, with their body measuring eighty-four thousand yojanas long and wide. Because the karma of this person's body, speech, and mind is heavy, they cannot escape.
Why is it so?
Because their mind cannot give rise to wholesome dharmas.
Even if innumerable Buddhas appear in the world, they will not hear or see them. Therefore, they are called 'always drowning,' like a large fish in the Ganges River.
Good man!
Although I have said that icchantikas and others are called 'always drowning,'
there are also those who are always drowning but are not icchantikas.
Who are they?
It is like a person who, for the sake of existence, cultivates giving, precepts, and wholesome deeds. This is called 'always drowning.'
Good man!
There are four wholesome things that lead to bad consequences.
What are the four?

First, reading and reciting the scriptures for the sake of surpassing others; second, observing precepts for the sake of profit; third, practicing giving for the sake of being attached to others; fourth, contemplating with focused mind for the sake of the realm of neither perception nor non-perception. These four wholesome things lead to bad consequences.
If a person cultivates these four things, it is called sinking and then emerging, emerging and then sinking again.
Why is it called sinking?
Because of delighting in the three realms of existence.
Why is it called emerging?
Because of seeing the light, the light being hearing, precepts, giving, and concentration.
Why is it called sinking again?
Because of increasing wrong views and giving rise to arrogance.
Therefore, I spoke this verse in the sutra:
If there are sentient beings who delight in the various realms of existence, they create good and bad karma for the sake of existence.
This person loses the path to nirvana, it is called temporarily emerging and then sinking again.
Although they practice in the dark sea of birth and death and attain liberation, they are still mixed with afflictions,
This person will still receive evil karmic retribution, which is called temporarily emerging and then sinking again.
Good man!
Like that giant fish, because it sees light, it temporarily emerges from the water.
But because its body is heavy, it sinks again.
The above two people are also like this.
Good man!
If a person delights in and clings to the three realms of existence, this is called sinking.
If they hear this MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra and give rise to faith, this is called emerging.
For what causes and conditions is it called emerging?
After hearing this sÅ«tra, they will distance themselves from evil dharmas and cultivate good dharmas, which is called emerging.
Although this person has faith, it is not complete.
For what causes and conditions is the faith incomplete?
Although this person has faith in the great parinirvÄá¹‡a, permanence, bliss, self, and purity, they say that the TathÄgata's body is impermanent, without self, without bliss, and without purity.
The TathÄgata then has two kinds of nirvÄá¹‡a:
The first is conditioned, and the second is unconditioned.
The conditioned nirvÄá¹‡a is impermanent, blissful, self, and pure, and the unconditioned nirvÄá¹‡a has permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Although they have faith that buddha-nature exists in sentient beings, it is not necessarily the case that all of them have it, and therefore it is called incomplete faith.
Good son!
Faith is of two kinds:
The first is faith, and the second is seeking.
This kind of person, although they have faith, is unable to investigate and seek, and therefore it is called incomplete faith.
Faith is of two kinds:
The first arises from hearing, and the second arises from contemplation.
This person's faithful mind arises from hearing and not from contemplation, and therefore it is called incomplete faith.
There are two kinds:
First, believing in the existence of the path, second, believing in those who attain it.
This person's faith only believes in the existence of the path, and does not believe at all in those who attain the path, and therefore it is called incomplete faith.
There are two more kinds:
First, believing in the correct, second, believing in the deviant.
Saying there are causes and effects, and there are Buddhas, Dharma, and Sangha, this is called believing in the correct.
Saying there are no causes and effects, the natures of the Three Jewels are different, and believing in various deviant words, PÅ«raá¹‡a KÄÅ›yapa and others, this is called believing in the deviant.
Although this person believes in the Three Jewels of Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, they do not believe that the Three Jewels have the same nature and characteristics.
Although they believe in causes and effects, they do not believe in those who attain them.
Therefore, it is called incomplete faith.
This person, having accomplished incomplete faith, also has incomplete precepts that they have received.
For what reasons is it called incomplete?
Because the causes are incomplete, the precepts that are obtained are also incomplete.
For what other reasons is it called incomplete?
There are two kinds of precepts:
First, the precepts of deportment, and second, the precepts of restraint.
This person only possesses the precepts of deportment, and does not possess the precepts of restraint, therefore it is called incomplete precepts.
There are two more kinds:
First, precepts of action, and second, precepts of non-action.
This person only possesses the precepts of action, and does not possess the precepts of non-action, therefore it is called incomplete precepts.
There are two more kinds:
First, obtaining right livelihood from body and speech, and second, not obtaining right livelihood from body and speech.
This person, although from body and speech, does not obtain right livelihood, therefore it is called incomplete precepts.
There are two more kinds:
First, seeking precepts, and second, abandoning precepts.
This person only possesses the precepts of seeking existence, and does not obtain the precepts of abandoning, therefore it is called incomplete precepts.
There are two more kinds:
First, following existence, and second, following the Way.
This person only possesses the precepts that follow existence, not the precepts that follow the Way, and therefore it is said that the precepts are incomplete.
There are two other kinds:
First, good precepts; second, evil precepts.

Good deeds of body, speech, and mind are called good precepts, while the precepts of cows and dogs are called evil precepts. This person deeply believes that these two kinds of precepts both have good results, and therefore it is said that the precepts are incomplete.
This person does not possess the two things of faith and precepts, and the learning they cultivate is also incomplete.
What is meant by incomplete learning?
The twelve divisions of the scriptures spoken by the TathÄgata, they only believe in six divisions and do not believe in six divisions, and therefore it is said that the learning is incomplete.

Although they accept and uphold these six divisions of the scriptures, they are unable to read, recite, or explain them to others, and are of no benefit, and therefore it is said that the learning is incomplete.

Moreover, having received these six types of sÅ«tras, for the sake of debate, for the sake of surpassing others, for the sake of gain, for the sake of existence, one upholds, recites, and explains them. Therefore, it is called incomplete hearing.
Good man!
I have explained in the sÅ«tras what is meant by complete hearing.
What is meant by completeness?
If there is a bhiká¹£u whose body, speech, and mind are good, who is able to make offerings to the preceptors, teachers, and virtuous people,
these teachers will give rise to a mind of loving-kindness towards this person. For this reason, they will teach him the Dharma.

This person, with utmost sincerity, receives and upholds, recites and studies. Having recited and studied, they attain wisdom. Having attained wisdom, they are able to skillfully contemplate and abide in accordance with the Dharma. Having skillfully contemplated, they attain the true meaning. Having attained the true meaning, body and mind are tranquil. With body and mind tranquil, they give rise to a joyful mind. Due to the condition of a joyful mind, the mind attains concentration. Because of attaining concentration, they attain right knowledge and insight. Having attained right knowledge and insight, they give rise to disgust and regret towards the mind of existence. Because of regretting existence, they are able to attain liberation.
This person does not have such matters, and therefore it is said that they are incomplete in hearing.
This person is incomplete in these three matters, and their giving is also incomplete.
There are two kinds of giving:
First, giving of wealth; second, giving of the Dharma.
Although this person practices giving of wealth, it is for the sake of seeking existence;
Although they practice giving of the Dharma, it is also incomplete.
Why is it so?
Because of fear of being surpassed by others, he does not fully explain it. Therefore, it is called incomplete giving.
There are two kinds of giving of wealth and Dharma:
One is holy, and the other is not holy.
The holy one gives without seeking rewards.
The unholy one gives while seeking rewards.
The holy one's Dharma giving increases the Dharma, while the unholy one's Dharma giving increases various existences.
Such a person practices giving of wealth in order to increase wealth, and practices giving of Dharma in order to increase existences. Therefore, it is called incomplete giving.

Furthermore, this person accepts the six kinds of scriptures and provides for those who accept the Dharma, but does not provide for those who do not accept the Dharma. Therefore, it is called incomplete giving.
This person is not endowed with the above four things, and his cultivated wisdom is also incomplete.
The nature of wisdom is able to discriminate, but this person is unable to discriminate whether the TathÄgata is permanent or impermanent.

The TathÄgata in this Nirvana Sutra says, 'The TathÄgata is precisely liberation, liberation is precisely the TathÄgata, the TathÄgata is precisely nirvana, nirvana is precisely liberation,' but in this meaning he is unable to distinguish.ğŸ”½'The pure practice is precisely the TathÄgata, the TathÄgata is precisely loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity are precisely liberation, liberation is precisely nirvana, nirvana is precisely loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity,' but in this meaning he is unable to distinguish, and therefore it is called 'lacking in complete knowledge.'

Furthermore, he is unable to distinguish the buddha-nature, the buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata, the TathÄgata is precisely all the uncommon dharmas, the uncommon dharmas are precisely liberation, liberation is precisely nirvana, nirvana is precisely the uncommon dharmas, but in this meaning he is unable to distinguish, and therefore it is called 'lacking in complete knowledge.'

What is meant by increasing unwholesome dharmas?

This person does not see their own incompleteness, but says they are complete, and gives rise to an attached mind. Among those with the same practice, they consider themselves superior, and therefore they associate with bad friends who are the same as themselves.

Having become intimate, they further hear incomplete teachings, and upon hearing them, their minds are delighted and their minds become attached, giving rise to arrogance and indulging in much negligence. Due to negligence, they become intimate with householders and enjoy hearing about household affairs, distancing themselves from the pure teachings of renunciation. For these reasons, they increase unwholesome dharmas.
Because of increasing unwholesome dharmas, they give rise to impure actions of body, speech, and mind.
Because of the impurity of the three karmas, they increase hell, animal, and hungry ghost realms. This is called temporarily emerging but quickly sinking back.

The second kind of person deeply knows and sees that their practice is incomplete. Because of incompleteness, they seek to be close to good friends. Because of being close to good friends, they enjoy consulting about what they have not yet heard. Having heard, they enjoy receiving it. Having received it, they enjoy skillfully contemplating it. Therefore, I spoke this verse in the sÅ«tra:
If a person is skilled in discerning meaning, with utmost sincerity seeking the fruits of Å›ramaá¹‡ahood,
If able to rebuke all existence, this person is called abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
If able to make offerings to immeasurable buddhas, then able to cultivate the path for immeasurable eons,
If enjoying worldly pleasures without negligence, this person is called abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
Intimately befriending the virtuous and listening to the true Dharma, internally well contemplating and abiding in accordance with the Dharma,
Enjoying seeing light and cultivating the path, attaining liberation and abiding in peace.
Good man!
There are five things lacking in wisdom. Having understood this, one seeks to befriend the virtuous.
Such a good friend should observe this person's greed, anger, delusion, and thoughts, which one is more excessive?

If it is known that this person has more greed, then they should be taught the method of contemplating impurity. If anger is more excessive, they should be taught loving-kindness and compassion. If thoughts are more excessive, they should be taught to count the breath. If attachment to self is more excessive, they should be taught to analyze the eighteen realms and so forth.

Having heard this, this person should accept it with a sincere mind. Having accepted it with a sincere mind, they should practice in accordance with the Dharma. Having practiced in accordance with the Dharma, they will gradually attain the contemplation of the four foundations of mindfulness, observing the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas. Having attained this contemplation, they will next contemplate the twelve links of dependent arising. Having contemplated in this way, they will next attain the stage of heat.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
All sentient beings possess the stage of heat.
Why is it so?
As the Buddha has said, the combination of three dharmas is called a sentient being: first, life; second, warmth; third, consciousness.
If it is from this principle, all sentient beings should have heat first. Why did the TathÄgata say that the heat factor arises from good friends?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
As you ask, those who have the heat factor, all sentient beings up to icchantikas all have it.
As for the heat factor I am now speaking of, it must arise from skillful means, and only then can it be obtained. It did not exist before but exists now.
For this reason, it is not that all sentient beings have it from the beginning. Therefore, you should not now argue that all sentient beings have the heat factor.
Good man!
This heat factor is a dharma of the form realm, not of the desire realm.
If it is said that all sentient beings have it, then sentient beings of the desire realm should also have it;
Since it does not exist in the desire realm, one should know that not all necessarily have it.
Good man!
Although it exists in the form realm, not all have it.
Why is it so?
My disciples have it, but non-Buddhists do not.
For this reason, not all sentient beings necessarily have it all.
Good man!
All non-Buddhists only contemplate six practices, while my disciples are fully endowed with sixteen. Not all sentient beings necessarily have all sixteen practices.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
What is the so-called 'warmth' dharma?
Is it naturally warm,
or is it warm because of others?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
This warmth dharma is naturally warm, not warm because of others.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa said:
World-Honored One!
The Tathagata previously said that AÅ›vajit and PÅ«rá¹‡a do not have the warmth dharma.
Why is it so?
Because they have no faith in the Three Jewels, they therefore have no warmth.
One should know that faith is precisely the warmth dharma.
Good man!
Faith is not the warmth dharma.
Why is it so?
Because one attains warmth through faith.
Good man!
Warmth is wisdom.
Why is it so?
Because it contemplates the four truths.
Therefore, it is called the sixteen aspects, and the aspects are wisdom.
Good man!
As you ask, why is it called warmth?
Good man!
Warmth is the sign of the fire of the eightfold noble path, and thus it is called warmth.
Good man!
It is like rubbing sticks to make fire, first there is warmth, then fire appears, and finally smoke comes out.
The uncontaminated path is also like this. Warmth is the sixteen aspects. Fire is the srota-Äpatti-phala. Smoke is the cultivation of the path to eliminate the bonds.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

Thus, the stage of heat is also a conditioned dharma, also a conditioned phenomenon. It is a dharma that can be attained through karmic retribution and has the five aggregates of the form realm. Therefore, it is called existence.
Because of these causes and conditions, it is also called conditioned.
If it is conditioned, how can it serve as the characteristic of the uncontaminated path?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
It is just as you have said.
Good man!

Thus, although the stage of heat is a conditioned dharma and a conditioned phenomenon, it can still destroy conditioned dharmas and conditioned phenomena. Therefore, it can serve as the characteristic of the uncontaminated path.
Good man!
It is like a person riding a horse, loving it and also spurring it on.

The heated mind is also like this. Because of love, one takes rebirth. Because of disgust, one contemplates practice. Therefore, although it is a dharma and a conditioned phenomenon, it can serve as the characteristic of the correct path.
One who has attained the stage of heat is of seventy-three kinds. In the desire realm, there are ten kinds.

Such a person is fully endowed with all afflictions, and from severing one part up to nine parts, like the desire realm, the first dhyÄna, up to the sphere of nothingness, is also like this. This is called the seventy-three kinds.
Such people, having attained the heat dharma, are then no longer able to sever wholesome roots, commit the five heinous crimes, or violate the four grave prohibitions.
There are two kinds of such people:
one encounters good friends, and the other encounters evil friends.
Those who encounter evil friends temporarily emerge but quickly sink back.
Those who encounter good friends thoroughly observe the four directions. Observing the four directions is precisely the summit dharma.
Although this dharma is by nature the five aggregates, it also takes the four truths as objects. Therefore, it is called thoroughly observing the four directions.
Having attained the summit dharma, one next attains the dharma of patience.
This patience is also like this. Its nature is also the five aggregates, and it also takes the four truths as objects.
This person next attains the supreme worldly dharma. Although this dharma is by nature the five aggregates, it also takes the four truths as objects.

This person gradually attains the acceptance of the doctrine of suffering. The nature of acceptance is wisdom, which takes one truth as its object. In this way, after the acceptance of the doctrine has taken one truth as its object, up to the elimination of afflictions to be eliminated by the path of seeing, one attains the fruit of stream-entry. This is called the fourth observation of the four directions. The four directions are the four noble truths.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

As the Buddha previously said, the afflictions eliminated by a stream-enterer are like water forty li long and wide, and the remaining [afflictions] are like a single hair's worth of water. Why is it said here that the elimination of the three bonds is called stream-entry?
First, the view of self; second, the view of what is not a cause as a cause; third, doubt.
World-Honored One!
For what causes and conditions is it called stream-entry to observe the four directions?
Moreover, for what causes and conditions is it called stream-entry?
Moreover, for what causes and conditions is the analogy of a salmon used to describe a stream-enterer?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Although the srota-Äpanna can eliminate innumerable afflictions, these three are heavy, and also include all the bonds eliminated by the srota-Äpanna.
Good man!
It is like when a great king goes out on a tour of inspection, although there are four troops, the people of the world only say the king comes and goes. Why is this?
Because the king is important in the world.
These three afflictions are also like this.
For what causes and conditions are they called heavy?
Because they are constantly aroused by all sentient beings and are subtle and difficult to recognize, they are therefore called heavy.
These three bonds are difficult to eliminate, can be the causes of all afflictions, and are the enemies of the three antidotes, namely precepts, concentration, and wisdom.
Good man!
There are sentient beings who hear that the srota-Äpanna can eliminate such innumerable afflictions, and then give rise to a defeatist attitude, saying:
How can sentient beings eliminate such innumerable afflictions?
Therefore, the TathÄgata skillfully expounds the three.
As you ask, why is a srota-Äpanna person likened to observing the four directions?
Good man!
A srota-Äpanna person observes the four truths and attains four things:
First, abiding in the firm path; second, being able to thoroughly contemplate; third, being able to see as it truly is; fourth, being able to destroy the great enemy.
The firm path refers to the five faculties possessed by a srota-Äpanna, which cannot be moved by others. Therefore, it is called abiding in the firm path.
Being able to thoroughly contemplate means being able to rebuke internal and external afflictions.
Seeing as it truly is refers to the knowledge of acceptance.
Destroying the great enemy refers to the four inverted views.
As you ask, why is it called srota-Äpanna?
Good man!
Srota means undefiled, and Äpanna means cultivation. Cultivating the undefiled is called srota-Äpanna.
Good man!
There is also a name for those who need it, called flow. Flow has two kinds:
One is the flow of conformity, and the other is the flow of going against the stream. Because of going against the flow, it is called srota-Äpanna.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
If it is according to this meaning, for what causes and conditions are those of the stage of srota-Äpanna, saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin, anÄgÄmin, and arhat not called srota-Äpanna?
Good man!
From the stage of srota-Äpanna up to the buddhas, they are also called srota-Äpanna.
If those of the stage of saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin up to the buddhas have no srota-Äpanna, how can they be called saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin up to buddhas?
There are two kinds of names for all sentient beings:
One is old, and the other is new.
When they are ordinary beings, they have worldly names. After attaining the Way, they are given new names, called srota-Äpanna.
Because they attained it first, they are called srota-Äpanna.
Because they attained it later, they are called saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin.
Such a person is also called a stream-enterer, also called a once-returner, and so on, up to the Buddha being the same way.
Good man!
There are two kinds of streams:
one is liberation, the other is nirvana.
All sages have these two, and can also be called stream-enterers, also called once-returners, and so on, up to the Buddha being the same way.
Good man!
Stream-enterers are also called bodhisattvas.
Why is this?
Bodhisattvas are precisely the knowledge of extinction and the knowledge of non-arising.
Stream-enterers also seek these two knowledges, therefore one should know that stream-enterers can be called bodhisattvas.
Stream-enterers can also be called enlightened.
Why is this?

Because they correctly realize the path and sever afflictions, correctly realize causes and effects, correctly realize the common and uncommon paths, once-returners up to arhats are also the same way.
Good man!
There are two kinds of stream-enterers:
those with sharp faculties and those with dull faculties.
Those with dull faculties take seven rebirths in the heavens and among humans, and those with dull faculties are further divided into five types: some take six, five, four, three, or two rebirths.
Those with sharp faculties attain the fruit of stream-entry up to the fruit of arhatship in the present life.
Good man!
As for your question about why a stream-enterer is likened to a salmon,
good man!
A salmon has four things:
first, its bones are fine and light; second, it has wings and is light; third, it enjoys seeing light; fourth, it holds onto its object firmly.

Srota-Äpannas also have four things. The phrase bones are fine is a metaphor for subtle afflictions. The phrase having wings is a metaphor for Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ. The phrase enjoying seeing light is a metaphor for seeing the path. The phrase holding onto an object firmly is a metaphor for hearing the TathÄgata speak of impermanence, suffering, no-self, and impurity, and firmly holding onto it without letting go.
It is just like when MÄra transformed into the appearance of a Buddha, and Elder ÅšÅ«ra saw it and was startled.
When MÄra saw that the elder's mind was moved, he said to the elder:
The four noble truths that I spoke of earlier are not true.
Now I will explain the five truths, six aggregates, thirteen entrances, and nineteen elements for you.
When the elder heard this, he examined the characteristics of the Dharma and found that none of it made sense, so he firmly held onto it and his mind did not move.
Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Because this srota-Äpanna has attained the path first, he is called a srota-Äpanna.
Because of being the first fruit, it is called the stream-enterer.

If one who has already attained the path is called a stream-enterer, why is it that when one attains the acceptance of the truth of suffering, one is not called a stream-enterer but rather one who is heading towards it?

If one is called a stream-enterer because of being the first fruit, then why is it that non-Buddhists who have previously severed afflictions up to the sphere of nothingness and cultivated the uncontaminated path to attain the fruit of non-returner not called stream-enterers?
Good man!
Because of being the first fruit, it is called the stream-enterer.

As for your question as to why non-Buddhists who have previously severed afflictions up to the sphere of nothingness and cultivated the uncontaminated path to attain the fruit of non-returner are not called stream-enterers,
good man!
Because of being the first fruit, it is called the stream-enterer. At that time, one is fully endowed with the eight knowledges and the sixteen aspects.
KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
Attaining the stage of non-returner is also like this. One also attains the eight knowledges and possesses the sixteen aspects. Why is it not called the stage of stream-entry?
Good man!
The sixteen aspects with outflows are of two kinds:
one is shared, the other is not shared.
The sixteen aspects without outflows are also of two kinds:
one is directed towards the fruits, the other is the attainment of the fruits.
The eight knowledges are also of two kinds:
one is directed towards the fruits, the other is the attainment of the fruits.

A person in the stage of stream-entry abandons the shared sixteen aspects and attains the unshared sixteen aspects, and abandons the eight knowledges directed towards the fruits and attains the eight knowledges of the attainment of the fruits.
A person in the stage of non-returner is not like this. Therefore, the initial fruit is called the stage of stream-entry.
Good man!

A person in the stage of stream-entry takes the four noble truths as objects, while a person in the stage of non-returner only takes one truth as an object. Therefore, the initial fruit is called the stage of stream-entry.
For this reason, it is likened to a carp that observes everywhere it goes.

The practitioner refers to the saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin who fixes his mind to cultivate the path in order to eliminate desire, anger, ignorance, and pride, like that carp, who observes all directions and then moves in order to eat, and after moving, stays still;
it is like the anÄgÄmin who obtains food and stays.
This anÄgÄmin generally has two kinds:
The first is the one who attains the state of anÄgÄmin in the present life and by further cultivation immediately attains the fruit of arhatship;
The second is the one who is attached to the tranquil samÄdhi in the form realm and formless realm. This person does not accept a body in the desire realm, so he is called an anÄgÄmin.
This anÄgÄmin also has five kinds:

The first is parinirvÄá¹‡a in the middle, the second is parinirvÄá¹‡a after rebirth, the third is parinirvÄá¹‡a through practice, the fourth is parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice, and the fifth is parinirvÄá¹‡a as an upward stream.
There are also six kinds:
The five kinds are the same as above, adding parinirvÄá¹‡a in the present life.
There are also seven kinds:
The six types are as above, plus parinirvÄá¹‡a in the formless realm.
Those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through practice are of two kinds:
either they take two bodies or four bodies.
If they take two bodies, they are of sharp faculties; if they take four bodies, they are of dull faculties.
There are also two kinds:
one is diligent but without mastery of samÄdhi, the other is lazy but has mastery of samÄdhi.
There are also two kinds:
one is endowed with diligence and samÄdhi, the other lacks both.
Good man!
Beings in the desire and form realms have two kinds of karma: one is active karma, the other is karma that produces rebirth.
Those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state only have active karma and not karma that produces rebirth, and therefore they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.

They abandon the body of the desire realm and have not yet reached the form realm, and because of their sharp faculties, they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, which is parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
Non-returners have four kinds of minds:
First, those who are neither learners nor post-learners, second, learners, third, post-learners, and fourth, those who are neither learners nor post-learners enter nirvana.
Why is it also called 'middling parinirvÄá¹‡a'?
Good man!
Among the four kinds of minds of the non-returners, two are nirvÄá¹‡a and two are not nirvÄá¹‡a. Therefore, it is called 'middling parinirvÄá¹‡a.'
The parinirvÄá¹‡a of those who take rebirth is also of two kinds:
First, that which is created by action, and second, that which is created by birth.
This person abandons the body of the desire realm and receives the body of the form realm. They diligently cultivate the path and, at the end of their life, enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
If it is said that they enter parinirvÄá¹‡a at the end of their life, how can it be called 'parinirvÄá¹‡a of those who take rebirth'?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
This person receives a body and then severs the afflictions of the three realms. Therefore, it is called 'parinirvÄá¹‡a of those who take rebirth.'
Good man!

Those who attain nirvana through practice constantly cultivate the path and, through the power of conditioned samÄdhi, are able to sever afflictions and enter nirvana. This is called attaining nirvana through practice.

Those who attain nirvana without practice are certain to attain nirvana, and therefore are lazy. Also, through the power of conditioned samÄdhi, when their lifespan is exhausted they are able to enter nirvana. This is called attaining nirvana without practice.

Those who attain nirvana as an upward stream are those who attain the fourth dhyÄna but give rise to a mind of attachment to the first dhyÄna in this life. Due to this cause and condition, they regress and are reborn in the first dhyÄna.
This has two streams:
The stream of afflictions and the stream of the path.
Due to the stream of the path, when their lifespan is exhausted, they give rise to attachment to the second dhyÄna. Due to attachment, they are reborn in the second dhyÄna.
Up to the fourth dhyÄna it is the same.
Within these four dhyÄnas there are two kinds:
Entering the formless realm and entering the five pure abodes.
These two types of people, one who enjoys samÄdhi and one who enjoys wisdom.
Those who enjoy wisdom enter the five pure abodes;
those who enjoy samÄdhi enter the formless realm.
These two types of people, one who cultivates the fourth dhyÄna with five levels of distinction and one who does not cultivate.
What are the five?
Lower, middle, upper, upper-middle, and upper-upper.
Those who cultivate the upper-upper level dwell in the Heaven of No Smallness.ğŸ”½Those who cultivate the upper-middle level dwell in the Heaven of Good Vision.
Those who cultivate the upper level dwell in the Heaven of Good Appearance.
Those who cultivate the middle level dwell in the Heaven of No Heat.
Those who cultivate the lower level dwell in the Heaven of Little Wides.
These two types of people, one who enjoys debate and one who enjoys tranquility.
Those who enjoy tranquility enter the formless realm, while those who enjoy debate dwell in the five pure abodes.
There are two more types;
one who cultivates perfumed meditation and one who does not cultivate perfumed meditation.
Those who cultivate and refine meditation enter the five pure abodes, while those who do not cultivate and refine meditation are reborn in the formless realm.
They attain parinirvÄá¹‡a at the end of their lives. This is called the parinirvÄá¹‡a of those who go upstream.

If one wishes to enter the formless realm, one cannot cultivate the four dhyÄnas and five distinctions. If one cultivates the four dhyÄnas and five distinctions, one can then rebuke the samÄdhi of the formless realm.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state have sharp faculties. If they have sharp faculties, why do they not enter parinirvÄá¹‡a in the present?
Why is there parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state in the desire realm but not in the form realm?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
This person's present four elements are weak and cannot cultivate the path.

Although there are bhiká¹£us whose four elements are healthy, they do not have dwellings, food and drink, clothing, bedding, or medicine. Since the necessary conditions are not complete, they cannot attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the present.
Good man!
I remember once in the past, when I was in the AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada Monastery in ÅšrÄvastÄ«, a bhiká¹£u came to where I was and said this:
World-Honored One!
I always cultivate the path, but I am unable to attain the fruit of stream-entry up to the fruit of arhatship.
I then told Ä€nanda:
You should now provide all the necessary things for such a bhiká¹£u.
At that time, Ä€nanda took this bhiká¹£u to the Jetavana Grove and gave him a good dwelling place.
The bhiká¹£u then said to Ä€nanda:
Venerable One!
Please adorn the dwelling place for me, make it clean and well-maintained, with the seven treasures, hanging silk banners and canopies.
Ä€nanda said:
The poor in the world are called Å›ramaá¹‡as. How can I accomplish such a thing?
The bhiká¹£u said:ğŸ”½Venerable One!
If you can do it for me, that would be excellent, excellent!
If he is unable to do so, I will return to the World-Honored One.'
At that time, Ä€nanda went to the Buddha and said:
'World-Honored One!
The bhiká¹£u just now asked me for various adornments, seven-jeweled banners and canopies. I wonder how to deal with this matter?'
I then told Ä€nanda:
'You should now return and provide the bhiká¹£u with whatever he needs.'
At that time, Ä€nanda returned to his room and provided the bhiká¹£u with everything he needed.
After obtaining them, the bhiká¹£u focused his mind on cultivating the path, and before long he attained the fruit of stream-entry up to the fruit of arhatship.
Good man!
Immeasurable sentient beings should enter nirvÄá¹‡a, but because of their lack [of requisites], their minds are disturbed, and therefore they are unable [to attain nirvÄá¹‡a].
Good man!

There are also sentient beings who delight in teaching and transforming others, but their minds are busy and they cannot attain concentration, so they are unable to attain nirvÄá¹‡a in the present life.
Good man!
You asked, For what causes and conditions is there parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state after abandoning the body in the desire realm, but not in the form realm?
Good man!
This person observes that the causes and conditions for afflictions in the desire realm are twofold:
First, internal; second, external.
The form realm is devoid of external causes and conditions.
The desire realm also has two kinds of craving:
First, craving for desire; second, craving for form.
Observing these two kinds of craving, one earnestly rebukes them. Having rebuked them, one can enter nirvÄá¹‡a.

In the desire realm, one can rebuke the coarse afflictions, namely stinginess, greed, anger, jealousy, shamelessness, and lack of conscience. For these causes and conditions, one can attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
Moreover, the path in the desire realm is by nature courageous and strong.
Why is it so?
Because it attains the four fruits.
Therefore, there is parinirvÄá¹‡a in the desire realm, but not in the form realm.
Good sons!
There are three kinds of parinirvÄá¹‡a in the middle: superior, middling, and inferior.
The superior one is one who discards the body and attains nirvÄá¹‡a without leaving the desire realm.
The middling one is one who has just left the desire realm and has not yet reached the form realm, and then attains nirvÄá¹‡a.
The inferior one is one who has left the desire realm and reaches the edge of the form realm to attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
It is like a carp that stops when it has found food. This person is also like this.
What is meant by stopping?
Dwelling in the form realm and formless realm, one can attain a body, and therefore it is called stopping.
Not accepting the human, heavenly, hellish, animal, or hungry ghost realms of the desire realm, and therefore it is called stopping.
Having already severed innumerable afflictive bonds, the remaining few are left, and therefore it is called stopping.
For what other reason is it called stopping?
One never creates things in common with ordinary beings, and therefore it is called stopping.
Having no fear oneself and not causing fear in others, this is called abiding.
Far removed from the two kinds of craving, greed, and anger, this is called abiding.
Good man!
Those who reach the other shore are like arhats, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and buddhas, like a divine tortoise that moves both in water and on land.
Why is it compared to a tortoise?
Because it skillfully conceals its five limbs.
Arhats up to buddhas are also like this, skillfully covering the five sense faculties, and therefore it is compared to a tortoise.
As for water and land, water is compared to the world, and land to the supramundane.
These sages are also like this, able to contemplate all evil afflictions, and therefore reach the other shore, and therefore it is compared to moving both in water and on land.
Good man!
In the Ganges River there are seven kinds of beings, although they have the names of fish and turtles, they are not apart from the water.
In this way, in this subtle great nirvÄá¹‡a, from icchantikas up to buddhas, although there are different names, they are still not apart from buddha-nature, which is like water.
Good man!

These seven kinds of beings, whether good dharmas, bad dharmas, the path of skillful means, the path of liberation, the successive path, causes, or effects, are all buddha-nature. This is called the TathÄgata's speech that accords with his own understanding.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
If there is a cause, then there is an effect. If there is no cause, then there is no effect.
NirvÄá¹‡a is called an effect, because it is permanent, it has no cause.
If it has no cause, how can it be called an effect?
This nirvÄá¹‡a is also called a Å›ramaá¹‡a and the fruit of a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
What is a Å›ramaá¹‡a?
What is the fruit of a Å›ramaá¹‡a?
Good man!
There are seven kinds of fruits in the world:

First, the fruit of skillful means; second, the fruit of repaying kindness; third, the fruit of intimacy; fourth, the remaining fruit; fifth, the equal fruit; sixth, the fruit of retribution; seventh, the fruit of separation.
As for the fruit of skillful means, it is like people in the world who harvest a lot of grain in autumn, all saying they have obtained the fruit of skillful means.
The fruit of skillful means is called the fruit of karmic practice.
This kind of fruit has two kinds of causes:
First, the proximate cause; second, the distant cause.
The proximate cause refers to the seeds.
The distant cause refers to water, fertilizer, and human effort.
This is called the fruit of skillful means.
As for the fruit of repaying kindness, it is like people in the world who make offerings to their parents, and the parents all say:
We have now obtained the fruit of being cared for.
The child's ability to repay kindness is called the fruit.
This kind of fruit also has two kinds of causes:
First, the proximate cause; second, the distant cause.
The proximate cause is the pure and wholesome karma of the parents in the past.
The distant cause is the filial child who is born.
This is called the fruit of repaying kindness.
The fruit of intimacy is like a person who becomes intimate with a good friend and attains the fruit of stream-entry up to the fruit of arhatship. This person proclaims:
'I have now attained the fruit of intimacy.'
This kind of fruit has two kinds of causes:
one is the proximate cause, and the other is the distant cause.
The proximate is the mind of faith, and the distant is the good friend.
This is called the fruit of intimacy.
The remaining fruit is like attaining the third body by the cause of not killing, prolonging life and increasing longevity. This is called the remaining fruit.
This kind of fruit has two kinds of causes:
one is the proximate cause, and the other is the distant cause.
The proximate is the purity of body, speech, and mind.
The distant is prolonging life and increasing longevity.
This is called the remaining fruit.
The equal effect refers to the vessel of the world.
This effect also has two kinds of causes:
one is the proximate cause, and the other is the distant cause.
The proximate cause refers to sentient beings cultivating the ten wholesome deeds.
The distant cause refers to the three calamities.
This is called the equal effect.
The retribution effect refers to when a person attains a pure body and cultivates the pure three karmas of body, speech, and mind, this person will say:
'I have attained the retribution effect.'
This kind of effect has two kinds of causes:
one is the proximate cause, and the other is the distant cause.
The proximate cause refers to the purity of the present body, speech, and mind.
The distant cause refers to the purity of the past body, speech, and mind.
This is called the retribution effect.
The effect of separation refers to nirvana, which is separated from all afflictions and all wholesome actions.
This cause of nirvana also has two kinds:
The first is the proximate cause, and the second is the distant cause.
The proximate cause is the three gates of liberation.
The distant cause is the wholesome dharmas cultivated over immeasurable eons.
Good son!
In worldly dharmas, sometimes a generative cause is spoken of, and sometimes a revealing cause is spoken of;
The supramundane dharmas are also like this, sometimes a generative cause is spoken of, and sometimes a revealing cause is spoken of.
Good son!

The three gates of liberation and the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment can serve as the generative cause for the non-arising of all afflictions, and also serve as the revealing cause for nirvana.
Good son!
Being far removed from afflictions, one can clearly see nirvana. Therefore, nirvana only has a revealing cause and no generative cause.
Good son!
As for your question, what is a Å›ramaá¹‡a?
What is the fruit of a Å›ramaá¹‡a?
Good son!

The Å›ramaá¹‡a is the eightfold right path, and the fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a is the complete and permanent severing of all greed, anger, and delusion that comes from the path. This is called the Å›ramaá¹‡a and the fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
For what causes and conditions is the eightfold right path called the Å›ramaá¹‡a?
Good man!
The word Å›ramaá¹‡a in the world is called 'lacking,' and the word na is called 'path.' Such a path cuts off all lacking and all paths.
For this reason, the eightfold right path is called the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Because one attains the fruit from this path, it is called the fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Good man!
Moreover, the Å›ramaá¹‡a is like a person in the world who enjoys tranquility and is also called a Å›ramaá¹‡a.

Such a path is also like this, able to cause the practitioner to leave behind the evil of body, speech, and mind, wrong livelihood, and so forth, and attain the bliss of tranquility. Therefore, it is called the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Good man!
Just as a person of lower status can become a person of higher status, this is called a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
This path is also like this, able to make a person of lower status become a person of higher status, therefore it is called a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Good man!
A person of arhatship who cultivates this path attains the fruit of a Å›ramaá¹‡a, therefore it is called reaching the other shore.

The fruit of arhatship is precisely the five parts of the Dharma body of one beyond training - precepts, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and vision of liberation. Because of these five parts one reaches the other shore, therefore it is called reaching the other shore.
Because one reaches the other shore, one says to oneself:
'My births are exhausted, the pure life has been established, what was to be done has been done, I will not experience another existence.'
Good man!
Because an arhat permanently severs the causes and conditions of birth in the three times, therefore he says to himself, 'My births are exhausted.'
It also severs the fruits of the five aggregates in the three realms, and therefore it is said again that 'my birth is ended.'
Because the pure practice has been completed, it is therefore proclaimed that 'the pure life has been established.'
Moreover, abandoning the path of learning is also called 'established.'
As originally sought, it has been attained today, and therefore it is proclaimed that 'what was to be done has been accomplished.'
Cultivating the path and attaining the fruits is also called 'accomplished.'
Because of attaining the knowledge of extinction and the knowledge of non-arising, it is proclaimed that 'my birth is ended' and 'all bonds of existence are ended.'
For this reason, it is called 'arhat' and 'reaching the other shore.'
Just as with the arhat, it is the same for the pratyekabuddha.

The bodhisattva and the Buddha fully accomplish the six perfections and are called 'reaching the other shore.' This Buddha and bodhisattva attaining supreme perfect enlightenment is called 'fully possessing the six perfections.'
Why is it so?
Because they attain the fruits of the six perfections, and because they attain the fruits, they are called complete.
Good man!

These seven kinds of beings do not cultivate the body, do not cultivate precepts, do not cultivate the mind, do not cultivate wisdom, and are unable to cultivate these four things. They are then able to commit the grave offenses of the five heinous crimes, cut off good roots, violate the four grave prohibitions, and slander the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha. Therefore, they are called those who are always submerged.
Good man!

Among these seven kinds of people, there are those who are able to draw near to good and virtuous friends, listen to and accept the TathÄgata's true Dharma with utmost sincerity, contemplate it well within, abide in accordance with the Dharma, and diligently cultivate the body, precepts, mind, and wisdom. Therefore, they are called those who cross the river of birth and death and reach the other shore.
If there are those who say that icchantikas can attain anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, this is called attachment;
if they say they cannot attain it, this is called false.
Good man!
